revision.text: {{also|Yangtsé}} ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|Yang-tse}} ===Etymology=== An irregular romanization of the {{bor|en|cmn|-}} pronunciation of {{bor|en|zh|揚子}} and {{m|zh|揚子江|tr=Yángzǐ Jiāng}}, q.v. ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{alternative form of|en|Yangtze}} #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1875 |origdate=February 22, 1875 |last=Oxenham |first=E. L. |title=VI.—On the Inundations of the Yang-tse-Kiang. |journal={{w|The Journal of the Royal Geographic Society of London}} |url=https://archive.org/details/s572id13663830/ |volume=45 |location=[[London]] |publisher={{w|John Murray (publishing house)|John Murray}} |issn=0266-6235 |oclc=66168045 |page=170 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/s572id13663830/page/170/ |text=The only claim the writer has to deal with this subject is that of having resided some three years at Han-kow, a large city of 700,000 inhabitants, situated in the province of Hu-pe, on the banks of the '''Yang-tse''', at the place where the Han River enters it, some 600 miles from the sea, situated in the centre of the flooded districts. |brackets=on}} #* {{quote-book |en |url=https://archive.org/details/aav8314.0001.001.umich.edu/ |year=1926 |author=Lucian Swift Kirtland |title=Finding the Worth While in the Orient |location=[[New York]] |publisher={{w|Robert M. McBride}} & Company |page=192 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/aav8314.0001.001.umich.edu/page/192/}} #*:A stream called the Han River separates Hankow from Hanyang, and these two towns, together with Wu-chang across the '''Yangtse''', are known as the Wu-Han cities. The steel mills, which are often referred to as the "Hankow mills," are at Hanyang. #* {{quote-book |en |year=1938 |last=Berkov |first=Robert |title=Strong Man of China: The Story of Chiang Kai-shek |url=https://archive.org/details/strongmanofchina0000berk |location=Boston |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company |page=146 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/strongmanofchina0000berk/page/146/ |text=War, real but undeclared, broke out at Shanghai on January 28, 1932. Two days later the National government which Chiang Kai-shek had established five years before at Nanking was moved to Loyang, far from the menace of Japanese men-of-war on the '''Yangtse'''.}} #* {{quote-book |en |url=https://archive.org/details/escapeofamethyst00phil/ |year=1957 |title=Escape of the ''Amethyst'' |author=C. E. Lucas Phillips |location=[[New York]] |publisher={{w|Coward-McCann}} |page=10 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/escapeofamethyst00phil/page/10/}} #*:This is the '''Yangtse'''—the '''Yangtse''' of the low-lying province of Kiangsu, from the ancient walled city of Chinkiang to the open sea—upon whose waters and along whose banks we shall live and move in this story. #* {{quote-book |en |year=2015 |author=Lawrie Ryan |title=Advanced Chemistry for You |url=https://archive.org/details/advancedchemistryforyou/ |edition=2nd |publisher={{w|Oxford University Press}} |ISBN=978 140 852736 8 |page=44 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/advancedchemistryforyou/page/n45/}} #*:The '''Yangtse''' River can burst its banks, flooding large areas of China. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=aegnsty|Gyantse|ageynst}}
